Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Basically, to avoid this kind of problems when working on opensource projects (or projects which have a lot of commiters) my practice is to create one squashed commit per change I'm working on, which I review when making PR. This way is much easier to trace changes which caused some problem, and maybe you can avoid commiting unwanted changes if you work on different fork that will contaminate other project....

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i wonder if the sapling tx serialization changing affects the CC signing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so the visitor.msg must match what was signed.

Author: jl777c#5810
jl777c#5810
Content: that is what calculates the sighash which i believe needs to match the vistor.msg, if they are not matched then we isolated the cause and can dig into why it is different

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: consensusBranchId <- that value changes when sapling activates!

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that could be a hint, i think it was 0 before

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so if the old code assumed consensusBranchId is 0, it would fail after sapling activation

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Ok, but why is it behaving that it sometimes work and sometimes not? If different value for consensusBranchId is used then it would fail all the time?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: clearly something is misbehaving, if we understood it we would know more about it. at this point we need to find the crash point and work from there.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we cant make sweeping assumptions like " If different value for consensusBranchId is used then it would fail all the time"

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe some code paths set it properly based on the value of an uninitialized variable

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe it is ok, at first but not after something updates internally

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: basically its random behavior means it can be almost anything

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe it has been there all along and only sapling activation exposed it

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Agree.

Content: since there is a clear signature failure and we are generating the sign in finalizeCCtx, it at least allows us to see if the sighash is conflicting

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i sure hope it is, as the alternative is getting into some real memory corruption scenarios
